By MARC DUVOISIN
University fund-raising officers
are now searching for possible
private and foundation donations
to support the proposed merit
scholarship program.
Though the merit proposal has
yet to be approved by the
Committee on Admissions and
Academic Services (CAAS) the
University administrators
appeared committed to
instituting such a scholarship
program within the next few
years.
"We are now trying to find
donors on the national scene who
are willing to sponsor merit
scholarships," said Larry Denton,
director of Academic Services
and author of the original
scholarship proposal.
"If there are foundations or
sponsors who are willing to
donate, we'll have to give serious
consideration to implementing
the program before too long," he
added.
Denton said he also feels that
CAAS members objected
primarily to minor points in the
merit proposal, not to the idea of
scholarship on merit."The major
concerns were about how the
scholarships would be funded,
and how recipients would be
selected. I don't believe the

committee had philosophical
objections."
"It was their consensus that
we should push ahead and try to
find answers to questions about
funding," said Denton.
Denton and other members of
CAAS have been encouraged by
the success of merit scholarship
programs at other private
universities, most notably
Vanderbilt and Duke.
"It seems that the scholarships
would be especially appropriate
for a small institution like
Hopkins," he said.
Scholarships on merit
Denton contends that
scholarships on merit would help
alleviate the plight of the middle
income students, who are often
ineligible for Financial Aid
though they are unable to meet
rising tuition costs.
He also asserts that the
scholarships would provide
publicity for some of the
University's undergradtiate
humanities programs, which are
not widely known among high
school students.
"I think it's important for us
to have a situation where we
could publicize our programs and
improve financial aid with
scholarships based on true
academic skills."

By BOB BUCHANAN
The early, unexpected
retirement of faculty member
John Walton June 30 has brought
about the abolition of all
course offerings in Education in
the Day school this semester.
Education courses will now be
offered only in the Evening
College, where Dr. Walton was
recently appointed to the
faculty.
Officially terminated in 1970,
the Education Department had
continued to offer a limited
number of courses while Walton
remained. "After the official
termination of the (Education)
Department, we carried just
those offerings John (Walton)
wanted to teach, " stated Dean
of Arts and Sciences George
Owen.
Walton, together with Dr.
Kingsley Price once headed a

department which included John
Holland, Julian Stanley, and
Timothy Smith. Holland was
appointed to the Social Relations
Department subsequent to the
Education Department's
abolishment, while Stanley is
now in the Psychology
Department.
Prior to 1970, the Education
Department offered both
undergraduate and graduate
degree programs in addition to
general interest courses. Hopkins
was an innovator in graduate
training for educators. The
Master of Arts in teaching
program began here in 1958.
Students with an interest in the
teaching profession from various
undergraduate majors were
admitted to the program.
The future of the Education
Department and the possibility
of it being returned to its former

status does not appear favorable.
Owen said,"It poses a big
problem. If you decide to
reinstate the Education
Department it would require a
big sum of money." He
continued, " We would have to
hire four to five new people.
With a current average cost of
$30,000 per faculty member
today the possibility is politically
complicated. Such an action
would have to be initiated by the
Academic Council."
The fate of seven graduate
students in education still
remaining after the department's
final demise last spring is
uncertain. Officially assigned to
Professor Smith, Owen stated the
"legitimate doctoral degrees" will
be conferred to them. However,
it has not been determined which
department will offer the
degrees.

To the Editor:
To take one job experience in
an industrial plant as an
experiment in American
ndustrial relations and call the
esults confirmatory of a
predetermined set of beliefs on
the subject is either a celestial
orocess of intuition or, more
likely, unwarranted
generalization. Yet, this is the
kind of errant logic served up to
political Science professor
Richard Pfeffer in a News-Letter
nterview report published
September 5 under the caption
s'Pfeffer Works with
Proletariat"—a Sabbatical job in a
Baltimore widget factory. He
:;eemed to tackle the job and
lraw conclusions with an
deological conditioned-reflex..
Dr. Pfeffer feels that
:ollective-bargaining is a
surreptitious dictatorship
qthordinating the worker and
that labor unions are
collaborationist . in the
implementation of the
agreements. If so, this is an

ethical reflection on the
protagonists rather than a charge
against the system itself. The
merits of unionization have
brought to the worker dignity,
due process and a bigger pay
check. The grievance process
makes effective determination in
disputes, and neutral outside
arbitration is brought in in case
of deadlock. The seniority
system is neither a senility nor
puerility system but a complex
and conscientious joint effort by
labor and management to protect
older workers and conserve skills.
The good foreman knows how to
get the work out and alert
management respects his
effectiveness and wisdom , and
acts on his suggestions on behalf
of employees. He is a valuable
intermediary. (Use of forewoman
and appropriate pronouns were
applicable.) There are shop
stewards constant as the North
Star (in Elizabethan astronomy)
in getting bad conditions
corrected. Unfortunately, layoffs
are a fact of industrial life, but

the superior, worker is not the
first to get laid off.
If the American worker boozes
it up once in a while, he can
afford it. There is no overtime
pay in China. The American
system is still the best. A lack of
historical perspective and a
monopole attraction to
presentism tend to obscure this
fact.
Perhaps on his next Sabbatical,
Dr. Pfeffer might take a job with
management and see the other
side of the coin and experience
the frustrations of management,
which are gargantuan by
comparison.
Finally, who are the
proletariat? Is there such a
political animal? Dr. Pfeffer does
not identity with the proletariat,
just as nobody identifies with
"the people." The terms conjure
up myths. The people are always
somebody else and can never be
found.
Arthur Dzura

Summer Theater's "Cyranno" ahead by a nose
By SUSAN OBRECHT
The JHU Summer Theatre's
production, " A Night with the
Theatre," featuring scenes from
Edmond Rostand's magnificent
play, "Cyranno de Bergerac,"
was presented last Wednesday
night in the Listening Viewing
room. Though the segments
which portrayed solely "Cyranno
de Bergerac' were often
imaginative and captivating, the
scenes and characters created by
Mr. Arellano's writing students
often lessened the dramatic
impact and strength of Rostand's
fine work.
An attempt was made by the
students to depict the
frustrations and challenges of
playwriting through the addition
of three new characters; Theatre
(Fran Birnbaum), Edmond
Rostand (Leon Epps) and an
audience member (Mark
Gallagher), who is later permitted
to take a role in "Cyranno." The
character Theatre encourages the

Playwright to finish his latest
Piece, while in the process the
audience hopefully learns about
the art of play', riting.
Unfortunately, this didactic
aspiration decreases the quality
of the show.
Theatre, dressed in a mimist
outfit, enters and introduces us
to the powers of the stage. Fran
Birnbaum fails to possess the
qualities of omnipotence and
strength inherent in her
description of the theatre.
Though dressed as a mimist she
lacks the precise and graceful
movements required of her role.
The necessary training in the
difficult art of mime might have
aided her movement and style.
Her dialogues are filled with trite
phrases such as "Faith is the one.
thing theatre and religion have in
Common." One finds it difficult
to have faith in statements like
this. But Theatre's delivery is as
unconvincing as her lines.
Theatre then coaxes an
awkward but curious audience
• member to the stage. Gallagher
seems to cope with his role well,
his gamin-like face endearing him
to the audience. After being
given a part in the play as a
Cadet, his amusing requests for
more dramatic lines often lighten
the otherwise dead interludes
between Theatre and Rostand.
Leon Epps, as the playwright
Rostand, is not persuasive in his
Portrayal of the frustrated artist
and fails to win the audience's

sympathy or understanding. The
type of frustration he elicits is
not, I am sure, what the
playwright had in mind.
Unfortunately, this clever
project seems to have fallen
through. These additional scenes
disrupt the energy so -carefully
built by Cyranno.
David Hodges, as Cyranno de
Bergerac, is excellent, one might
say inspired, and is perhaps the
one reason to see this show.
Cyranno is a difficult role which
provides a challenge for even the
most mature actors. Hodges
captures the dichotomy in
Cyranno's personality. His Public
side of histrionics and dramatic
speeches is best displayed in his
'retort to Valvcrt (Joachim
Blunck) concerning his grandiose
nose. The covert sensitive facet
of Cyranno's complex character
is movingly revealed in his
devotion and deep love for
Rozanne.
With the aid of the excellent

portrayals of Ragneau (Rodney
Florek) and Lise (Liz Wallace),
despite the 1 blase characterizations of DeGuiche (Albert
Donay) and Le Bret (Alan
Schwartz), Hodges bring

moments of dramatic impact to
his scenes.
Roxanne (Ellen Bernhard), the
beautiful cousin of Cyranno, is
meant to be as beautiful as he is
ugly, as lacking in compassion as
he is compassionate. In this
interpretation, one feels that she
is a misplaced character ;she has
recently stepped off the set of
"Gone With the Wind." Ellen
Bernhard attains the
coquettishness and vanity which
Roxanne is known for, yet seems
tos have taken these qualities to
extremes, simpering to the point
of _seeming a Southern belle. The
director,. John Heavey, would
have done well to control her
awkward facial muggings; her
rolling eyes and pursed lips.
Further, Roxannr does care
about Cyranno nut his concern
seems forgotten. Often her most
tender proclamations become
ludicrous in her all too saccharine
performance.
Roxanne loves the youthful
and handsome Christian (Jeff
Engel) who lacks the eloquence
of Cyranno yet holds strong
passion for Roxanne. This too is
a difficult role, but is performed
well. In his portrayal, Christian's
verbal weakness never distorts
the strength of his love for
Roxanne.
This trio shares a most
sparkling moment in the
balcony scene in which
Roxanne listens to cyranno speak
the words which Christian only
wishes he could.
Yet perhaps the weakest scene
from "Cyranno" is that in which
Roxanne visits Christian and
Cyranno on the battlefield. The
apparently impromtu belches and
burps of the soldiers receive more
laughs than the proper words of
Rostand and as a result all
concentration descends in this
segment.
Generally, the scenes from
"Cyranno de Bergerac" reach
heights of dramatic power. But
the energy and tension which
Hodges works so hard to create is

cb
cb

lost when it is placed in contrast
to the scenes involving Theatre
and Rostand. In the death scene,
Cyranno brings the audience to
an emotional climax, only to
have Theatre and Rostand's last
scene disappoint us and lessen
the quality of the total
production.
The 'director has made an
admirable endeavor in this work.
Yet perhaps he should have
concentrated more on revealing
the depth of the lesser characters.
His settings were imaginative and
suitable to the logistics of the LV
room.
Several times in the show the
lights and the music did not
coincide with the direction of
Theatre, yet it was unclear if
these are planned "flaws" or
technical difficulties.
Furthermore, the lighting
often fails to set the proper tone

whether it be the bleakness of
the battlefield or the romantic
mood of the balcony scene.
Despite the overly hirsute
moustaches of many of the
cadets and the smudging of the
chalky white powder on
Theatre's hair and costume, the
make-up is well done. Special
praise should be given to
Cyranno's convincingly grotesque
nose.
JHU's Summer Theatre
production makes an ambitious
attempt to consider the difficult
art of playwriting in their version
of "Cyranno." Though this part
of the project fails, the dry but
delicate wine served during
intermission, and, even more,
Hodge's superb performance, are
not to be missed. The last
performance will be given
Saturday night at 8 pm in the
Listening Viewing Room.

Rollerball bringing together the worst
By DAVID SIEGMAN
A man is being relentlessly
bludgeoned by a group of
attackers. One hears the dull
thud of blows to the flesh, and
then metal searing through skin,
like the sound you might hear
when cutting cardboard with
scissors. The victim lies staring
blankly into space as blood
trickles slowly down his forehead
in a jagged line.
The scene is from Rollerball, a
movie now playing at several area
theatres. When it became certain
that the victim was dead, a large
middle-aged woman to my left,
in an oversized "Keep on
Trucicin" T-shirt and equally
sagging hairnet, emitted a shrill
cackling laugh. Two kids sitting
behind me vigorously applauded.
The audience appeared to be
enjoying the violence almost as
much as those engaging in the
attack on the screen.
The movie is about the future,
where corporations rule the
world and there are no wars. But
man's violent nature needs an
outlet, so we have rollerball. I

won't enumerate the rules of
rollerball. Suffice to say it is
somewhere between a
particularly zesty roller derby
game and a gladiator match.
In the movie Rollerball,
violence is seen as a sport, and
altogether too many viewers are
enjoying it. One central theme of
the movie is that violence can be
fun. The crowds in the theater
who approve of the Nimrods on
ball bearings are no less perverse
than the crowds in the film itself,
who also. shriek their approval.
To derive pleasure from watching
humans being murdered is
certainly an act of depravity.
And one of the objects of
rollerball is to kill the opponent.
Pleasures
So, you modern day
epicureans, here's another to add
to your list. True, the more
established pleasures are also
found in Rollerball. The sybaritic
protagonist, Jonathan E.,(played
well by James Caan when you
could hear him) boozes it up,
entertains his always fresh supply
of playmates, and still finds time

to pop pills. He delights in these
thrilling events in a house that
would've made Frank Lloyd
Wright give it all up and sell hot
pretzels. So far, so good; but our
hedonistic hero really has a
better time playing rollerball
than busying himself with all the
other jollies.
If movies like Rollerball serve
as a harbinger of what is to come,
a new genre may be upon us.
Violence will be portrayed as
sport, and enjoy wide popularity.
Even in facist-like movies such as
Dirty Harry and Death Wish,
sport was not the prevalant
violence type, if found at all. The
killer-heroes even felt remorseful
at times. People have always
enjoyed certain forms of
violence, but a line must be
drawn as to what is normal and
what is not. Movies like
Rollerball can't be compared to a
Kilgore Trout explosion into
absurdity. Maybe it would be
better if they could, but actions
such as one which took place in
the National Hockey League last
winter are testimonies to the

contrary. Harsh words were
exchanged between two players
during a hockey game, resulting
in an attempt by one player to
gouge out the eye of the other
with a hockey stick. The victim,
Henry Boucha, has been
physically scarred for life, and
has double vision. The attacker,
David Forbes, was not jailed,
fined or penalized in any way.
The jury failed to reach a verdict.
Fantasy
The implications of this
episode are alarming, and one
realizes that rollerball is not an
immaterial fantasy. This violent
game and others like it must be
deplored, lest we cultivate a
society geared to accepting such
debauchery. Any possible
redeeming message in the movie
is eclipsed by large doses of
violence. It is unlikely that
direcf or Norman Jewison
coincidentally contrived the
situation whereby the
protagonist was forced to cause
senselesss death to achieve his
goal. No, his violence is
deliberate and inexcusable.

from within itself. Actually. I'm

not so much concerned with
what the shape is...I'm interested
in the 'light drama.' Light is an
integral part...in fact, it's the
most important part of the
sculpture."
Brown went on to say,
"Light's been here since time
began, and I've decided to use it.
Unlike Sandy Calder, who said,
'Light. That's what the electric
company makes,' I list light as
one of the materials I work with.

marble, dig?"

esthetics of the design, "I knew
that it was meant for the

A pictorial chronicle of the

6 p.m. daily and from 1 p.m. to 6
p.m. on Sundays. They are open
to the public without charge.
Among the featured

The early, unexpected

about the abolition of all

abolishment, while Stanley is
now in the Psychology
Department.

Department offered both
undergraduate and graduate
degree programs in addition to
general interest courses. Hopkins
was an innovator in graduate
training for educators. The
Master of Arts in teaching
program began here in 1958.

teaching profession from various
undergraduate majors were
admitted to the program.

reinstate the Education

big sum of money." He

hire four to five new people.

complicated. Such an action
would have to be initiated by the
Academic Council."

To the Editor:
To take one job experience in
an industrial plant as an
experiment in American
ndustrial relations and call the
esults confirmatory of a
predetermined set of beliefs on
the subject is either a celestial
orocess of intuition or, more
likely, unwarranted
generalization. Yet, this is the
kind of errant logic served up to
political Science professor
Richard Pfeffer in a News-Letter
nterview report published
September 5 under the caption
s'Pfeffer Works with
Proletariat"—a Sabbatical job in a
Baltimore widget factory. He
:;eemed to tackle the job and
lraw conclusions with an
deological conditioned-reflex..
Dr. Pfeffer feels that
:ollective-bargaining is a
surreptitious dictatorship
qthordinating the worker and
that labor unions are
collaborationist . in the
implementation of the
agreements. If so, this is an

ethical reflection on the
protagonists rather than a charge
against the system itself. The
merits of unionization have
brought to the worker dignity,
due process and a bigger pay
check. The grievance process
makes effective determination in
disputes, and neutral outside
arbitration is brought in in case
of deadlock. The seniority
system is neither a senility nor
puerility system but a complex
and conscientious joint effort by
labor and management to protect
older workers and conserve skills.
The good foreman knows how to
get the work out and alert
management respects his
effectiveness and wisdom , and
acts on his suggestions on behalf
of employees. He is a valuable
intermediary. (Use of forewoman
and appropriate pronouns were
applicable.) There are shop
stewards constant as the North
Star (in Elizabethan astronomy)
in getting bad conditions
corrected. Unfortunately, layoffs
are a fact of industrial life, but

the superior, worker is not the
first to get laid off.
If the American worker boozes
it up once in a while, he can
afford it. There is no overtime
pay in China. The American
system is still the best. A lack of
historical perspective and a
monopole attraction to
presentism tend to obscure this
fact.
Perhaps on his next Sabbatical,
Dr. Pfeffer might take a job with
management and see the other
side of the coin and experience
the frustrations of management,
which are gargantuan by
comparison.
Finally, who are the
proletariat? Is there such a
political animal? Dr. Pfeffer does
not identity with the proletariat,
just as nobody identifies with
"the people." The terms conjure
up myths. The people are always
somebody else and can never be
found.

Summer Theater's "Cyranno" ahead by a nose
By SUSAN OBRECHT
The JHU Summer Theatre's
production, " A Night with the
Theatre," featuring scenes from
Edmond Rostand's magnificent
play, "Cyranno de Bergerac,"
was presented last Wednesday
night in the Listening Viewing
room. Though the segments
which portrayed solely "Cyranno
de Bergerac' were often
imaginative and captivating, the
scenes and characters created by
Mr. Arellano's writing students
often lessened the dramatic
impact and strength of Rostand's
fine work.
An attempt was made by the
students to depict the
frustrations and challenges of
playwriting through the addition
of three new characters; Theatre
(Fran Birnbaum), Edmond
Rostand (Leon Epps) and an
audience member (Mark
Gallagher), who is later permitted
to take a role in "Cyranno." The
character Theatre encourages the

Playwright to finish his latest
Piece, while in the process the
audience hopefully learns about
the art of play', riting.
Unfortunately, this didactic
aspiration decreases the quality
of the show.
Theatre, dressed in a mimist
outfit, enters and introduces us
to the powers of the stage. Fran
Birnbaum fails to possess the
qualities of omnipotence and
strength inherent in her
description of the theatre.
Though dressed as a mimist she
lacks the precise and graceful
movements required of her role.
The necessary training in the
difficult art of mime might have
aided her movement and style.
Her dialogues are filled with trite
phrases such as "Faith is the one.
thing theatre and religion have in
Common." One finds it difficult
to have faith in statements like
this. But Theatre's delivery is as
unconvincing as her lines.
Theatre then coaxes an
awkward but curious audience
• member to the stage. Gallagher
seems to cope with his role well,
his gamin-like face endearing him
to the audience. After being
given a part in the play as a
Cadet, his amusing requests for
more dramatic lines often lighten
the otherwise dead interludes
between Theatre and Rostand.
Leon Epps, as the playwright
Rostand, is not persuasive in his
Portrayal of the frustrated artist
and fails to win the audience's

sympathy or understanding. The
type of frustration he elicits is
not, I am sure, what the
playwright had in mind.
Unfortunately, this clever
project seems to have fallen
through. These additional scenes
disrupt the energy so -carefully
built by Cyranno.
David Hodges, as Cyranno de
Bergerac, is excellent, one might
say inspired, and is perhaps the
one reason to see this show.
Cyranno is a difficult role which
provides a challenge for even the
most mature actors. Hodges
captures the dichotomy in
Cyranno's personality. His Public
side of histrionics and dramatic
speeches is best displayed in his
'retort to Valvcrt (Joachim
Blunck) concerning his grandiose
nose. The covert sensitive facet
of Cyranno's complex character
is movingly revealed in his
devotion and deep love for
Rozanne.
With the aid of the excellent

portrayals of Ragneau (Rodney
Florek) and Lise (Liz Wallace),
despite the 1 blase characterizations of DeGuiche (Albert
Donay) and Le Bret (Alan
Schwartz), Hodges bring

moments of dramatic impact to
his scenes.
Roxanne (Ellen Bernhard), the
beautiful cousin of Cyranno, is
meant to be as beautiful as he is
ugly, as lacking in compassion as
he is compassionate. In this
interpretation, one feels that she
is a misplaced character ;she has
recently stepped off the set of
"Gone With the Wind." Ellen
Bernhard attains the
coquettishness and vanity which
Roxanne is known for, yet seems
tos have taken these qualities to
extremes, simpering to the point
of _seeming a Southern belle. The
director,. John Heavey, would
have done well to control her
awkward facial muggings; her
rolling eyes and pursed lips.
Further, Roxannr does care
about Cyranno nut his concern
seems forgotten. Often her most
tender proclamations become
ludicrous in her all too saccharine
performance.
Roxanne loves the youthful
and handsome Christian (Jeff
Engel) who lacks the eloquence
of Cyranno yet holds strong
passion for Roxanne. This too is
a difficult role, but is performed
well. In his portrayal, Christian's
verbal weakness never distorts
the strength of his love for
Roxanne.
This trio shares a most
sparkling moment in the
balcony scene in which
Roxanne listens to cyranno speak
the words which Christian only
wishes he could.
Yet perhaps the weakest scene
from "Cyranno" is that in which
Roxanne visits Christian and
Cyranno on the battlefield. The
apparently impromtu belches and
burps of the soldiers receive more
laughs than the proper words of
Rostand and as a result all
concentration descends in this
segment.
Generally, the scenes from
"Cyranno de Bergerac" reach
heights of dramatic power. But
the energy and tension which
Hodges works so hard to create is

cb
cb

lost when it is placed in contrast
to the scenes involving Theatre
and Rostand. In the death scene,
Cyranno brings the audience to
an emotional climax, only to
have Theatre and Rostand's last
scene disappoint us and lessen
the quality of the total
production.
The 'director has made an
admirable endeavor in this work.
Yet perhaps he should have
concentrated more on revealing
the depth of the lesser characters.
His settings were imaginative and
suitable to the logistics of the LV
room.
Several times in the show the
lights and the music did not
coincide with the direction of
Theatre, yet it was unclear if
these are planned "flaws" or
technical difficulties.
Furthermore, the lighting
often fails to set the proper tone

whether it be the bleakness of
the battlefield or the romantic

Despite the overly hirsute
moustaches of many of the
cadets and the smudging of the

praise should be given to

nose.

production makes an ambitious
attempt to consider the difficult
art of playwriting in their version

Rollerball bringing together the worst
By DAVID SIEGMAN
A man is being relentlessly
bludgeoned by a group of
attackers. One hears the dull
thud of blows to the flesh, and
then metal searing through skin,
like the sound you might hear
when cutting cardboard with
scissors. The victim lies staring
blankly into space as blood
trickles slowly down his forehead
in a jagged line.
The scene is from Rollerball, a
movie now playing at several area
theatres. When it became certain
that the victim was dead, a large
middle-aged woman to my left,
in an oversized "Keep on
Trucicin" T-shirt and equally
sagging hairnet, emitted a shrill
cackling laugh. Two kids sitting
behind me vigorously applauded.
The audience appeared to be
enjoying the violence almost as
much as those engaging in the
attack on the screen.
The movie is about the future,
where corporations rule the
world and there are no wars. But
man's violent nature needs an
outlet, so we have rollerball. I

won't enumerate the rules of
rollerball. Suffice to say it is
somewhere between a
particularly zesty roller derby
game and a gladiator match.
In the movie Rollerball,
violence is seen as a sport, and
altogether too many viewers are
enjoying it. One central theme of
the movie is that violence can be
fun. The crowds in the theater
who approve of the Nimrods on
ball bearings are no less perverse
than the crowds in the film itself,
who also. shriek their approval.
To derive pleasure from watching
humans being murdered is
certainly an act of depravity.
And one of the objects of
rollerball is to kill the opponent.
Pleasures
So, you modern day
epicureans, here's another to add
to your list. True, the more
established pleasures are also
found in Rollerball. The sybaritic
protagonist, Jonathan E.,(played
well by James Caan when you
could hear him) boozes it up,
entertains his always fresh supply
of playmates, and still finds time

to pop pills. He delights in these
thrilling events in a house that
would've made Frank Lloyd
Wright give it all up and sell hot
pretzels. So far, so good; but our
hedonistic hero really has a
better time playing rollerball
than busying himself with all the
other jollies.
If movies like Rollerball serve
as a harbinger of what is to come,
a new genre may be upon us.
Violence will be portrayed as
sport, and enjoy wide popularity.
Even in facist-like movies such as
